abstract.p: Metricom, high-speed wireless Internet company backed by WorldCom and investor Paul Allen, to introduce high-speed wireless Internet service, Ricohet; customers of Ricohet, which costs $75 to $80 a month, get Internet access from laptop computers and some hand-held devices at higher speeds than are normally available on dial-up connections; Metricom chairman Timothy Dreisbach comments; photo (S)

block.p: Metricom, the highspeed wireless Internet company backed by WorldCom and the investor Paul Allen, will introduce its high-speed wireless Internet service, Ricochet, today in Manhattan, Baltimore, Dallas, Houston, Philadelphia, Phoenix and San Francisco. Customers of Ricochet, which costs $75 to $80 a month and is already available in San Diego, Atlanta, Seattle and Washington, get Internet access from laptop computers and some hand-held devices at higher speeds than are normally available on dial-up connections. ''This is the all-you-can-eat wireless experience, far beyond the mockery of Internet applications available on cell phones,'' Timothy Dreisbach, Metricom's chairman, said. Metricom plans to extend its network to 46 markets by next year.
